question_details.title: Will the Trump administration attempt to withdraw from key international arms control agreements in 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-03-18 15:33:28 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/36025). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

The Trump administration’s first term saw a pattern of withdrawing from international arms control agreements, including:

* **INF Treaty (**[**2019**](https://www.defense.gov/News/News-Stories/article/article/1924779/us-withdraws-from-intermediate-range-nuclear-forces-treaty/)**)** – U.S. withdrawal from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty with Russia.
* **Open Skies Treaty (**[**2020**](https://www.armscontrol.org/act/2020-12/news/us-completes-open-skies-treaty-withdrawal)**)** – Trump announced withdrawal, citing Russian non-compliance.
* **Iran Nuclear Deal (**[**2018**](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/08/world/middleeast/trump-iran-nuclear-deal.html)**)** – The U.S. exited the JCPOA, leading to renewed tensions.

With Trump's return to office in 2025, there is renewed concern that his administration may withdraw from key arms control agreements, particularly those seen as restricting U.S. military capabilities. The agreements most at risk include:

1. [**New START**](https://www.state.gov/new-start-treaty) **(Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty)**, the last remaining U.S.-Russia nuclear arms control treaty, limiting strategic nuclear warheads and delivery systems. It is set to expire in 2026, but there are concerns that Trump may refuse renewal or suspend compliance before then.
2. [**The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC)**](https://www.opcw.org/chemical-weapons-convention), a global ban on chemical weapons with strong bipartisan support, but potential friction due to compliance disputes with China and Russia.
3. [**The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT)**](https://disarmament.unoda.org/wmd/nuclear/npt/), the cornerstone of global nuclear non-proliferation. While withdrawal is unlikely, Trump has expressed skepticism toward arms control constraints in the past.
4. [**The Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT)**](https://www.ctbto.org/our-mission/the-treaty), though never ratified by the U.S., Trump officials previously floated the idea of resuming nuclear testing—potentially violating the spirit of the treaty.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":36025,"question_id":35459}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before January 1, 2026, credible sources report that the Trump administration has formally attempted to withdraw from or significantly reduce U.S. participation in at least one of the following seven international arms control agreements:

* New START (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty)
* The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC)
* The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT)
* The Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT)
* Biological Weapons Convention (BWC)
* Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons (CCW)
* Outer Space Treaty (OST)

A formal attempt to withdraw includes, but is not limited to, any of the following:

1. Official notification of withdrawal: The U.S. government formally notifies treaty partners, the United Nations, or other relevant bodies of its intent to exit an arms control agreement.
2. Legally binding action: The administration takes executive action, submits a withdrawal request to Congress (where required), or engages in legal or procedural steps toward exiting an agreement.
3. Suspension of compliance: The administration officially announces that it will no longer comply with the obligations of an agreement, effectively nullifying U.S. participation.
4. Substantive defunding: The administration or Congress enacts a significant funding cut (at least 50%) to an agreement’s implementation, undermining U.S. participation.

If no formal attempt to withdraw from any of the seven treaties is made by January 1, 2026, the question will resolve as **No**.
question_details.fine_print:
The question will *not* resolve as **Yes** based solely on:

* Rhetorical statements: If Trump or senior officials publicly criticize an agreement but do not take concrete steps to exit.
* Exploratory reviews: If the administration commissions a study or internal review on withdrawing but does not take formal action.
* Negotiated revisions: If the administration renegotiates an agreement but does not seek withdrawal.

***

* CTBT was never ratified by the US. Despite that, this question could still resolve based the US announcing a policy of non-compliance, as stated in criterion #3.
* New START is set to expire in February 2026. A non-extension would not resolve this question as **Yes**. The US would have to either withdraw before February 2026 or extend the treaty and withdraw afterwards.

If there is ambiguity regarding whether an attempt meets the criteria, expert assessments from organizations such as the [Arms Control Association](https://www.armscontrol.org/), [Brookings Institution](https://www.brookings.edu/), or [Council on Foreign Relations](https://www.cfr.org/) will be considered by Metaculus to resolve this question.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Trump suggests willing to extend arms control deal with Russia | News Flash**
US President Donald Trump stated on October 6, 2025, that he is open to extending the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START) with Russia, following a proposal from Russian President Vladimir Putin for a one-year extension. The treaty, signed in 2010 and set to expire on February 5, 2026, limits each side to 1,550 deployed nuclear warheads and 800 deployed and non-deployed ballistic missile launchers and heavy bombers, while also providing for mutual verification. However, inspections under the treaty have been suspended since Russia halted participation two years prior, amid the war in Ukraine and escalating Western tensions. Trump, who previously expressed interest in a negotiated denuclearization with Moscow and Beijing, has also directed the Pentagon to develop a large-scale missile defense system called Golden Dome. His response to Putin’s offer was: 'Sounds like a good idea to me.'
Original language: en
Publish date: October 06, 2025 02:53 AM
Source:[Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha (BSS)](https://www.bssnews.net/news-flash/318318)

**Trump Opens Door to Extending Nuclear Arms Treaty with Russia, Citing Putin's Proposal**
Donald Trump indicated on Sunday, October 5, 2025, that he is open to considering Russian President Vladimir Putin's proposal to extend the New START nuclear arms treaty—also known as START III—for one year, which would maintain limits on strategic nuclear arsenals. The treaty, set to expire on February 5, 2026, caps each nation's nuclear warheads at 1,550 and delivery systems at 700. Putin made the proposal on September 22, 2025, and emphasized that it would only be viable if the U.S. acts in a reciprocal manner and avoids actions undermining strategic deterrence. Russian UN ambassador Vassily Nebenzia stated Moscow continues to await Trump’s response. The proposal comes amid tensions over U.S. consideration of supplying Ukraine with long-range Tomahawk missiles, capable of reaching Moscow and much of European Russia, which Putin warned would 'lead to the destruction of our relations' or at least halt positive trends. Russia suspended implementation of the treaty on February 21, 2023, without formally withdrawing, halting Western inspections of Russian facilities. Trump did not provide details on current or future negotiations.
Original language: es
Publish date: October 05, 2025 07:52 PM
Source:[ADN Radio 91.7 Chile ](https://www.adnradio.cl/2025/10/05/trump-abre-la-puerta-a-extender-el-tratado-nuclear-con-rusia-propuesto-por-putin-me-parece-buena-idea/)

**Trump Welcomes Putin’s Proposal to Extend New START Treaty, Citing 'Good Idea'**
U.S. President Donald Trump responded to Russian President Vladimir Putin's proposal to extend the New START treaty—also known as START III—by saying, 'Me parece una buena idea' (It seems like a good idea), during a press briefing at the White House on October 5, 2025. The treaty, which expires on February 5, 2026, limits each country to 1,550 nuclear warheads and 700 strategic delivery systems. Putin made the proposal on September 22, 2025, during a Security Council meeting, emphasizing that extension would require reciprocal actions from the U.S. to preserve strategic deterrence parity. The Russian UN ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia, confirmed Moscow is awaiting Washington’s response. The offer comes amid tensions over U.S. consideration of supplying Ukraine with long-range Tomahawk missiles, capable of reaching Moscow and much of European Russia. Putin warned that such deliveries would 'lead to the destruction of our relations' with the U.S. or at least undermine recent positive trends. Russia suspended the treaty’s implementation on February 21, 2023, without formally withdrawing, halting Western inspections of Russian nuclear facilities. The New START treaty remains the last active arms control agreement between the two nuclear powers.
Original language: es
Publish date: October 05, 2025 06:30 PM
Source:[Deutsche Welle](https://www.dw.com/es/trump-sobre-propuesta-nuclear-de-putin-me-parece-buena-idea/a-74243695)

**US-Russia nuclear arms control: Trump says Putin's voluntary limits proposal 'sounds like a good idea' | Today News**
US President Donald Trump expressed support on October 5, 2025, for Russian President Vladimir Putin's proposal to voluntarily maintain limits on deployed strategic nuclear weapons beyond the expiration of the New START treaty in February 2026. Putin had suggested that Russia would continue adhering to the 2010 New START treaty’s caps—limiting deployed strategic warheads to 1,550 and delivery vehicles to 800—if the United States agrees to do the same. Trump stated the proposal 'sounds like a good idea to me,' indicating potential US interest in a follow-up agreement. The New START treaty has served as a cornerstone of US-Russia nuclear arms control, and its expiration has raised concerns about a renewed arms race. Trump’s openness to the proposal emerges amid ongoing debates over the future of strategic arms control and its implications for global security in Europe and Asia.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 05, 2025 04:25 PM
Source:[mint](https://www.livemint.com/news/us-news/usrussia-nuclear-arms-control-trump-says-putin-s-voluntary-limits-proposal-sounds-like-a-good-idea-11759680962702.html)

**Russia Welcomes Trump’s Response to Putin’s Proposal for Nuclear Arms Reduction Treaty Extension**
The Kremlin expressed optimism regarding U.S. President Donald Trump's response to Russian President Vladimir Putin's proposal to extend the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START III) for one year, beyond its expiration date of February 5, 2026. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitri Peskov stated, 'We welcome this statement and believe it already provides grounds for optimism that the United States supports this initiative from Putin.' Putin, who had proposed the extension on September 22, emphasized that it would only be viable if the U.S. acted in a similar manner and did not take actions undermining the current strategic deterrent balance. He labeled a potential U.S. withdrawal from the treaty—signed in April 2010 by U.S. President Barack Obama and Russian President Dmitri Medvedev—as 'erroneous' and 'short-sighted' from 'many perspectives.' Trump responded to reporters at the White House the previous day by calling Putin’s proposal a 'good idea.' Russia suspended the treaty’s implementation, though not formally denounced it, on February 21, 2023, which has since prevented Western specialists from inspecting Russian nuclear facilities. START III limits each side to a maximum of 1,550 nuclear warheads and 700 strategic delivery systems across land, sea, and air. In mid-September, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Riabkov acknowledged that negotiations to normalize U.S.-Russia relations were stalled.
Original language: es

Source:[El Aragueño](https://elaragueno.com.ve/rusia-saluda-reaccion-de-trump-a-propuesta-de-putin-sobre-tratado-de-desarme-nuclear/)

**Explainer: Could US and Russia extend last nuclear weapons treaty?**
On October 6, 2025, U.S. President Donald Trump responded positively to Russian President Vladimir Putin's proposal to voluntarily extend the New START Treaty limits on deployed strategic nuclear weapons for one year, following Putin's September offer. The New START Treaty, signed in 2010 by Presidents Barack Obama and Dmitry Medvedev and extended in 2021 by Putin and President Joe Biden, expires on February 5, 2026. Strategic nuclear weapons are long-range systems designed to impact the outcome of war by targeting centers of power, command structures, or critical infrastructure. Russia and the U.S. together possess about 87% of the world’s nuclear warheads—5,459 and 5,177 respectively, according to the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). Arms control treaties originated after the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis to reduce the risk of miscommunication and slow the arms race. However, with rising tensions over Ukraine and both nations modernizing arsenals, most treaties have collapsed, with each side blaming the other. Key issues include: U.S. plans for the $175-billion Golden Dome space-based missile defense system, which Russia views as destabilizing; mutual accusations over new weapons systems—Russia’s Oreshnik, Kinzhal, and Avangard, and U.S. strategic capabilities; divergent views on tactical nuclear weapons, with Russia holding 1,477 non-strategic warheads and the U.S. 200; U.S. superiority in strategic nuclear submarines; and the inclusion of China, which has about 600 warheads and is not willing to negotiate with nations with larger arsenals. Putin warned that Russia would conduct a nuclear test if another power does, citing intelligence of preparations by an unnamed country. The future of the one-year extension remains uncertain, as Putin stated further voluntary limits depend on U.S. actions.

**Cold War Echoes**
On September 22, 2025, Russian President Vladimir Putin announced a unilateral proposal to extend the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START) for one year, until February 2026. The treaty, signed by Barack Obama and Dmitri Medvedev in 2010, limits U.S. and Russian strategic nuclear arsenals to 1,550 deployed warheads and 700 launchers, with rigorous verification mechanisms. Russia has consistently adhered to the treaty, allowing U.S. inspections and data exchanges. In contrast, the U.S. has withdrawn from the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty (2002), the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty, and the Open Skies Treaty, weakening global arms control. There is growing pressure to include China in future agreements, but China has rejected participation in a U.S.-Russia framework. The author warns that demanding a multilateral treaty as a precondition risks collapsing the existing bilateral treaty, removing the last enforceable limits on nuclear arsenals. The article cautions that Europe’s misinterpretation of Russia’s gesture as weakness is dangerous, as Russia is not vulnerable but confident in its deterrent. Without New START, verification, data sharing, and notifications would cease, increasing the risk of miscalculation, accidents, and an unregulated arms race. The collapse of the INF Treaty already reduced reaction times to minutes, heightening danger. The author emphasizes that even a one-year extension provides critical time for diplomacy and maintains predictability, which is better than chaos. The decision to accept or reject the extension will determine global security for decades. The treaty expires in February 2026, and delay risks a future without rules, limits, or trust. He said that before resuming talks, Russia needed to understand what France and the United Kingdom were demanding and how to account for their NATO strike capabilities. It also stopped providing telemetry data on U.S. intercontinental ballistic missiles and ballistic missile submarines. At the end of December 2024, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov reminded that Russia still adhered to quantitative limits on strategic weapons under the treaty despite its suspension, and that until the U.S. abandons its anti‑Russian stance, ‘we will not engage in negotiations with them on arms control’.

Russian President Vladimir Putin warned that the global nuclear arms‑control system has been destroyed and offered to extend the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START) with the United States for one year if Washington commits to the same. summary:
All forecasting experts assess a low probability that the Trump administration will attempt to withdraw from key international arms control agreements before January 1, 2026. Across expert domains—ranging from U.S. foreign policy, arms control law, international relations (both realist and institutionalist), regime theory, security and deterrence studies, and rational choice theory—there is a clear consensus: while Trump’s first term set a precedent for withdrawing from some agreements (INF Treaty, Open Skies, JCPOA), the current public signals and diplomatic climate are markedly different.

Recent Trump statements repeatedly favor extending New START, with openness to Russian proposals and no public or bureaucratic moves toward formal withdrawal from any of the seven covered treaties (New START, CWC, NPT, BWC, CCW, OST, CTBT). Experts uniformly reject the idea that mere rhetoric or exploratory reviews would meet the strict resolution criteria, emphasizing that only formal, concrete steps—such as official notification, legal suspension, or significant defunding—would count.

Base rates of U.S. withdrawal from foundational arms control agreements like the NPT, CWC, BWC, and OST are described as extremely low or nearly zero; most historical withdrawals targeted less entrenched, more controversial agreements. Institutional inertia, bipartisan Congressional and military support, allied pressure, reputational risks, and bureaucratic hurdles all weigh strongly against the likelihood of formal withdrawal attempts in the next three months. The most plausible candidate for withdrawal—New START—is, according to all available signals, the subject of positive engagement and possible extension, further lowering immediate risk.

While experts acknowledge Trump’s unpredictability and the non-zero risk of abrupt policy shifts in response to a crisis (such as major escalation in Ukraine), all judge the probability to remain well below 20%, with most forecasts clustering between 6% and 15%. The consensus judgment is that the Trump administration will maintain participation in all seven arms control agreements through January 1, 2026, absent a dramatic and currently unforeseeable downturn in international security or domestic political dynamics.
